name: benzoic acid, 2-formyl-
Reason: The compound benzoic acid, 2-formyl- is made up of a benzene ring, a carboxylic acid group, and an aldehyde group. The basic melting point of benzene is 5.5 °C which we will use as a reference point. Carboxylic acids significantly increase the melting point due to their capacity for strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding and dimer formation; we can estimate this contribution to be around +100 °C. The aldehyde group contributes less to the melting point than the carboxylic acid group because it does not form hydrogen-bonded dimers, but it can still engage in hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, potentially contributing around +20 °C. However, given the actual melting point of the compound is 98.0 °C, these group contributions must be adjusted to match the known value. After considering the effects of both functional groups, additional stabilization from the conjugation of the aldehyde may also play a role.
